body.p: Depending on the medium you chose to install Gentoo from, you can or cannot continue without networking (and Internet). No, we are not playing with your mind =)
All Gentoo installations can succeed with a working Internet connection. If you want to install Gentoo without one, you need to use one of the following installation mediums:

ul.li: Gentoo x86 2-CD Installation LiveCD set (all subarchitectures)

body.p: Installing Gentoo from the Internet results in a fully updated Gentoo Installation. You'll have an installation based on the most recent Portage (which is the collection of packages we provide together with the tools to manage your software). This is also the reason why a network-installation is preferred. However, some people cannot install Gentoo from a system attached to the Internet...

For those people, some architectures provide a LiveCD with all necessary sourcecode and tools to install a Gentoo base system (or even beyond). However, this does come with the price of having not extremely recent software (although the differences between versions are slim).

Some paragraphs above we've explained who can use a networkless installation. If you do not plan on using the network and you use one of the listed installation mediums, then you can skip the rest of this section and continue with the next. Otherwise, continue with the networking configuration parts below.

If your system is plugged into an Ethernet network, it is very likely that your networking configuration has already been set up automatically for you. If so, you should be able to take advantage of the many included network-aware commands on the LiveCD such as ssh, scp, ping, irssi, wget and links, among others.
If networking has been configured for you, the /sbin/ifconfig command should list some network interfaces besides lo, such as eth0:

body.p: You may want to try pinging your ISP's DNS server (found in /etc/resolv.conf) and a Web site of choice, just to make sure that your packets are reaching the net, DNS name resolution is working correctly, etc..
Are you able to use your network? If so, you can skip the rest of this section. If not, bad luck, you'll have to persue a bit harder :)

Now test your network as we described above. Still no luck? Well then it's time to manually configure the network. Otherwise continue with the next section.

If all above fails, you will have to configure your network manually. Have no fear, it is far from difficult. But we are going to explain a certain amount of networking to you as you will need it to be able to configure your network satisfactory. When you're done reading this, you will know what a gateway is, what a netmask serves for and how a broadcast address is formed.
